David C. Graeber, Educator

Resources

My Process

today

Making progress requires a learning posture and commitment to consistently using data and feedback to continuously correct course and improve

Learning Context and Conditions

Creating equitable learning environments necessitates that we commit to a shared understanding of what we are all working toward in our respective areas or domains in the education system: 

Teacing and Learning

  • Nuture student agency, self directed learning and critical consciousness
  • Systematically gather and calue student feedback 
  • Provide frequent, formative, growth-oriented feedback that affirms high academic expectations and support for all students
  • Represent, affirm and support students to explore their personal, cultural, racial and academic identities

School-wide Systems and Structures: 

  • All school efforts, structures, resources and people align around a clear school wide vision of equitable learning and development and a shared underdstanding of why and how drives the work. 
  • Professional processes, structures and cultures build the individual and collective efficacy of educators and staff while supporting their personal well-being and providing opportunities for ongoing inquiry and critical reflection.
  • Systematic use of a broad range of disaggregated quantitative and qualitative data to enhance equitable opportunity, experience, and success.
  • Differentiated opportunities for students to develop and demonstrate mastery, with punitive or discriminatory grading practices identified and eliminated
  • School structures that promote student leadership and agency
  • Time and learning opportunities are flexibly designed and organized to prioritize student experience and learning goals
  • Cultivation of authentic learning experiences
  • The goals of discipline policies and practices are to support student learning and development rather than to punish or exclude students.

Family/Caregiver and Community Partnerships

  • Families and school staff work in authentic partnerships to develop and advance a shared definition of student success
  • Families and school staff build meaningful relationships that foster mutual trust, understanding and appreciation across cultures and other differences
  • Families and community members co-design and co-govern schools so that policies and practices are equitable and support all students

District and State Policies

  • System goals and aligned accountability policies focus on equitable whole students learning and development
  • Policies and resource allocations promote the development of school environments that support student safety, belonging, agency, wellness, and thriving
  • Policies and resources support the hiring and development for staff who have the mindsets and skills to build equitable and effective learning environments
  • Structures and requirements are in place to ensure authentic engagement of students, families, and communities in directing state and district policy and practice
  • State and district data and accountability systems support site-level focused continuous improvement processes
  • Resources are adequate and equitably distributed (i.e. allocate the most effective/experienced teachers with students most in need).
  • School leaders are held accountable for advancing these commitments while being given autonomy and ownership to find the most locally appropriate path to fulfill those commitments.
face

Consensus Based Decision Making

If consensus is reached on a proposal, a decision is made! 

If not, modifications are made to the proposal until consensus is reached. 

Members need not agree about every decision, but those who disagree must be willing to move forward; otherwise, consensus has not been achieved and a new proposal must be considered 

handshake

Accomplishments:

  1. Led the building of a K-12 STEM curriculum 
  2. Successfully negotiated several labor contracts inclusive of the most recent ratification of the IFA teachers contract.  
  3. Ushered in an era of the IUSFD 5 Year Strategic Plan. 
  4. Developing a goal based, theory of action accountability system for program evaluation and management. 
  5. Helped lead the district through 2 bond votes and construction of the beautiful Mezaros Field/Oley Track and the subsequent seating and outdoor pavillion, along with all of the other wonderful additions to make our campuses safe for students and staff.  
  6. Collaborated to enlarge a 5 member board to 7 trustees in order to provide more access and leadership opportunities for people to serve the wonderful children of our district.  
  7. Helped create the "Board Briefs" newsletter to build more transparency and communication bridges between the board and the community. 

And I am most proud of having helped lead us through an unprecented global pandemic in ways that will see us make even more progress and lead our students into a better future! 

Frequently Asked Questions

When is the Election?

Tuesday, May 17th, 2022 7AM - 9PM.

Where can I vote?

Please be advised that this year, voting will take place in the Main Street School gymnasium which is located directly next to the Irvington Police station and the beautiful Irvington Theater.

What happens if the budget does not pass?

In the case that the budget is voted down, the district has the opportunity to make adjustments and bring it back for a second vote.

Who should I vote for?

You should vote for David Graeber so we can continue to collaboratively make IUFSD the best school district in Westchester county!

If you have any questions or thoughts you would like to share, please feel free to complete the template below and I will get back to you ASAP!
